content: Thinking to the future and the fact that many governments are acting more and more like communist dictatorships instead of a democracy I see a possible time coming where they will want to subjugate everyone and dictate every movement and financial transaction in our lives, WEF Klaus Schwab said something along these lines at the beginning of the scamdemic, you will own nothing and be happy about it. Frankly I dont want to play any part in that kind of society at all.We need an aternate economy, one that is not controlled by government, not controlled by the Rothchilds banking cartel. If we stop using "Their" money their nasty little communist games are over.So, what providers, shops, goods and services do you all currently know of that offer bitcoin as an alternative payment source instead of fiat currency?Is there a bitcoin services directory?, if not perhaps there's an opportunity to create a yellow pages for bitcoin enabled shops and services.

comments.author: darkangel11
comments.body: You can always ask around if they take bitcoin. The more people ask the more companies will research bitcoin to satisfy their clients. If you just want to spend bitcoin instead of going through exchange process, send it to companies that sell gift codes. You may find that a store near you accepts bitcoin. For instance I gave my wife some codes to spend in Ikea and they worked very well. Now we have a new desk, lamp, an office chair and a few other gadgets and all the codes are gone  Give your woman some money and she'll find ways to turn it into goods and services

comments.author: Stalker22
comments.body: Quote from: Nexus9090 on August 17, 2024, 04:36:16 PM~Is there a bitcoin services directory?, if not perhaps there's an opportunity to create a yellow pages for bitcoin enabled shops and services.There is no definitive directory of businesses accepting cryptocurrency that Im aware of.  Just fragmented lists and forums where folks share their experiences.  Nothing fully comprehensive or up to date.  You make a fair point - there is certainly an opportunity here.  For example, I know a handful of local online shops that take crypto through localized payment processor.  Doubt they pop up on any radar.  So a crypto-centric Yellow Pages could prove useful.  Gathering that intel systematically to publish in one spot presents challenges however.   I suppose an enterprising soul could build a crowdsourced database.  Kick things off by listing known examples, then open it up for anyone to add qualifying businesses from their communities.  Verification process would need some rigor to keep things legit.

comments.author: Rruchi man
comments.body: Quote from: Nexus9090 on August 17, 2024, 04:36:16 PMIf we stop using "Their" money their nasty little communist games are over.Can we really stop using fiat entirely? It can be easier to use bitcoins to purchase things like a house, a car, or other properties or equipment, but there are little, petty things that we like to purchase sometimes, and these things may be equivalent to the transaction fees. Will you, as a bitcoin hodler, choose to use your bitcoins in the purchase of these sorts of things simply because a vendor will accept payment in bitcoins? I doubt.

comments.author: davis196
comments.body: QuoteIf we stop using "Their" money their nasty little communist games are over.So, what providers, shops, goods and services do you all currently know of that offer bitcoin as an alternative payment source instead of fiat currency?1.Spending Bitcoin for goods and services is stupid. The smart move is to spend altcoins and stablecoins for goods and services, but the problem is that there aren't many online(or offline) merchants accepting altcoin/stablecoin payments.2.Cash isn't evil. Cash is still anonymous. What is truly evil is the digital fiat money and the upcoming Central Bank Digital Currencies(or CBDCs). I don't mind spending fiat cash money for goods and services, since their value is going down every month.3.The Bitcoin/crypto world is becoming more and more compliant with the government regulations. comments.author: kryptqnick
comments.body: I don't share the op's view of the world turning "communist". I think there is significant authoritarian backlash over the last several years, and that democracy is globally challenged, but that we still live in some of the freest times in human history.In any case, Bitcoin welcomes people of various political standpoints, and it does offer an alternative to the traditional economy. How much you can directly use Bitcoin to buy goods and services depends on your region, but you can Google a map of places accepting Bitcoin (or use some of the links others have provided). Then just visit the places close to you and find out if it's accurate.
